The `state` is                     `0` for \"does not exist\", `1` for \"active\" and `2` for                     \"cancelled.\""},"request(bytes,bytes,uint64,address,uint8)":{"details":"The request can be a spent utxo and/or a created utxo.   ///                     The contract allows users to register a \"consumer\" contract                     that implements ISPVConsumer to handle Bitcoin events.   ///                     Bitcoin transactions are composed of a vector of inputs,                     and a vector of outputs. The `_spends` parameter allows consumers                     to watch a specific UTXO, and receive an event when it is spent.   ///                     The `_pays` and `_paysValue` param allow the user to watch specific                     Bitcoin output scripts. An output script is typically encoded                     as an address, but an address is not an in-protocol construction.                     In other words, consumers will receive an event whenever a specific                     address receives funds, or when a specific OP_RETURN is created.   ///                     Either `_spends` or `_pays` MUST be set. Both MAY be set.                     If both are set, only notifications meeting both criteria                     will be triggered. ","params":{"_consumer":"The address of a contract that implements the `ISPVConsumer` interface.                     Whenever events are available, the Relay will validate inclusion                     and confirmation, then call the `spv` function on the consumer. ","_numConfs":"The number of headers that must confirm the block                     containing the transaction. Used as a security parameter.                     More confirmations means less likely to revert due to a                     chain reorganization. Note that 1 confirmation is required,                     so the general \"6 confirmation\" rule would be expressed                     as `5` when calling this function ","_pays":"An output script to watch for events. A filter with `_pays` set will                     validate any number of events that create new UTXOs with a specific                     output script.   ///                     This is useful for watching an address and responding to incoming                     payments. ","_paysValue":"A minimum value in satoshi that must be paid to the output script.                     If this is set no any non-0 number, the Relay will only forward                     `_pays` notifications to the consumer if the value of the new UTXO is                     at least `_paysValue`. ","_spends":"An outpoint that must be spent in acceptable transactions.                     The outpoint must be exactly 36 bytes, and composed of a                     LE txid (32 bytes), and an 4-byte LE-encoded index integer.                     In other words, the precise serialization format used in a                     serialized Bitcoin TxIn.   ///                     Note that while we might expect a `_spends` event to fire at most                     one time, that expectation becomes invalid in long Bitcoin reorgs                     if there is a double-spend or a disconfirmation followed by                     reconfirmation. "},"return":"A unique request ID."}}},"userdoc":{"methods":{"cancelRequest(uint256)":{"notice":"Cancel an active bitcoin event request."},"fillRequest(bytes32,bytes,bytes,uint256,uint8,uint8)":{"notice":"Fill an active bitcoin event request."},"getRequest(uint256)":{"notice":"Retrieve info about a nodes.name: request
cancelRequest
fillRequest
getRequest
request
cancelRequest
fillRequest
getRequest

cancelRequest(uint256).details: Prevents the relay from forwarding tx information

params._requestID: The ID of the request to be cancelled

params._inputIndex: The index of the input in the _vin that triggered                     the notification.
params._outputIndex: The index of the output in the _vout that triggered                     the notification. Useful for subscribing to transactions                     that spend the newly-created UTXO.
params._requestID: The ID of the event request that this notification                     satisfies. The ID is returned by                     OnDemandSPV.request and should be locally stored by                     any contract that makes more than one request.
params._txid: The LE(!) txid of the bitcoin transaction that                     triggered the notification.
params._vin: The length-prefixed input vector of the bitcoin tx                     that triggered the notification.
params._vout: The length-prefixed output vector of the bitcoin tx                     that triggered the notification.

params._requestID: The numerical ID of the request

getRequest(uint256).return: A tuple representation of the request struct.                     To save space`spends` and `pays` are stored as keccak256                     hashes of the original information. The `state` is                     `0` for "does not exist", `1` for "active" and `2` for                     "cancelled."

request(bytes,bytes,uint64,address,uint8.details: The request can be a spent utxo and/or a created utxo.   ///                     The contract allows users to register a "consumer" contract                     that implements ISPVConsumer to handle Bitcoin events.   ///                     Bitcoin transactions are composed of a vector of inputs,                     and a vector of outputs. The `_spends` parameter allows consumers                     to watch a specific UTXO, and receive an event when it is spent.   ///                     The `_pays` and `_paysValue` param allow the user to watch specific                     Bitcoin output scripts. An output script is typically encoded                     as an address, but an address is not an in-protocol construction.                     In other words, consumers will receive an event whenever a specific                     address receives funds, or when a specific OP_RETURN is created.   ///                     Either `_spends` or `_pays` MUST be set. Both MAY be set.                     If both are set, only notifications meeting both criteria                     will be triggered.

params._consumer: The address of a contract that implements the `ISPVConsumer` interface.                     Whenever events are available, the Relay will validate inclusion                     and confirmation, then call the `spv` function on the consumer.
params._numConfs: The number of headers that must confirm the block                     containing the transaction. Used as a security parameter.                     More confirmations means less likely to revert due to a                     chain reorganization. Note that 1 confirmation is required,                     so the general "6 confirmation" rule would be expressed                     as `5` when calling this function
params._pays: An output script to watch for events. A filter with `_pays` set will                     validate any number of events that create new UTXOs with a specific                     output script.   ///                     This is useful for watching an address and responding to incoming                     payments.
params._paysValue: A minimum value in satoshi that must be paid to the output script.                     If this is set no any non-0 number, the Relay will only forward                     `_pays` notifications to the consumer if the value of the new UTXO is                     at least `_paysValue`.
params._spends: An outpoint that must be spent in acceptable transactions.                     The outpoint must be exactly 36 bytes, and composed of a                     LE txid (32 bytes), and an 4-byte LE-encoded index integer.                     In other words, the precise serialization format used in a                     serialized Bitcoin TxIn.   ///                     Note that while we might expect a `_spends` event to fire at most                     one time, that expectation becomes invalid in long Bitcoin reorgs                     if there is a double-spend or a disconfirmation followed by                     reconfirmation.

cancelRequest(uint256).notice: Cancel an active bitcoin event request.

fillRequest(bytes32,bytes,bytes,uint256,.notice: Fill an active bitcoin event request.

request(bytes,bytes,uint64,address,uint8.notice: Subscribe to a feed of Bitcoin transactions matching a request
